The formation and transformation of hexadecanal influence on reaction pathway and activity in the palmitic acid hydrodeoxygenation over mesoporous ETS-10 supported Ni catalyst Chaojie Zhu Investigation Formal analysis Visualization Writing – original draft a Wenqian Fu Validation Investigation Writing – original draft Funding acquisition Supervision Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Lei Zhang Formal analysis Funding acquisition b Yuan Zhang Investigation b Dongfang Wu Conceptualization Methodology Funding acquisition Project administration Resources Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Tiandi Tang Writing – original draft Methodology Resources Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing b a Department of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Jiangning District, Nanjing 211189, China Department of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Southeast University Jiangning District Nanjing 211189 China aDepartment of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Jiangning District, Nanjing 211189, China b School of Petrochemical Engineering, Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213164, China School of Petrochemical Engineering Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu 213164 China bSchool of Petrochemical Engineering, Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213164, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Mesoporous ETS-10 zeolites supported Ni catalysts (Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10) were applied in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of palmitic acid to investigate the formation and transformation pathways of hexadecanal (HAL) and reaction activity. Experiment results verified that HAL was an initial product in the HDO reaction under 0.1 MPa H2 pressure, and Ni@HMETS-10 exhibits higher activities (robs,1 =2.55×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1, robs,2 = 6.85×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) than Ni@NaMETS-10 (robs,1 =1.59×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1, robs,2 =5.74×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) due to the presence of Brönsted acid sites and highly dispersed Ni particles. At high H2 pressure (4.0 MPa), the acid-base properties of the support affected the transformation of HAL and the reaction pathways. The abundant Lewis basic sites on Ni@NaMETS-10 can promote the decarbonylation of the HAL and the HDCO route are dominate. Brönsted acid and Ni sites on Ni@HMETS-10 synergistically catalyzed the deoxygenation of palmitic acid via two parallel HDH2O and HDCO routes with a higher reaction rate (1.42×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) than Ni@NaMETS-10 (1.31×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1). The reaction rate constants of each step in reaction routes on both catalysts were supplemented. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mesoporous ETS-10 zeolite Ni-based catalyst Hexadecanal formation Palmitic acid Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The continuous depletion of fossil fuels and increasing concern for environmental protection have pressured to develop renewable biomass energy [1–3]. Bio-fuels, derived from microalgae or vegetable oils, are one of the greatly significant alternatives for the fossil fuels, due to its reproducibility and environmental benignity [4–6]. To obtain high-grade bio-fuels, the oxygen-containing compounds, such as long chain fatty acids and triglycerides that are the dominant components in the microalgae (or vegetable)-devried bio-oils must be underwent a hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) technology to eliminate the oxygen and be transformed into fuel-range hydrocarbons [6–8]. Therefore, HDO of bio-oil is a crucial upgrading process to produce high-grade fuels [9,10]. At present, various long chain (C16–C22) fatty acids, especially, stearic acid and palmitic acid are investigated extensively through HDO technique for the upgrading of bio-fuels [11–13]. As to the HDO of palmitic acid, there are existing three main deoxygenation routes in the catalysis process either on noble metal or transition metal catalysts (Fig. 1 ) [8,13–15]: one is decarboxylation route (DCO2) that palmitic acid is direct removal of one molecule of carbon dioxide to form pentadecane (n-C15); another is hydrodecarbonylation route (HDCO) that palmitic acid is hydrogenation-dehydrated to form hexadecanal (HAL) intermediate and followed by elimination of carbon monoxide to obtain pentadecane (n-C15); the third is hydrodeoxygenation route (HDH2O) that the HAL intermediate is continuous hydrogenated to form hexadecanol (HOL) and next undergoes hydrogenation/dehydration to get hexadecane product (n-C16). Because the noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ru) are expensive and scarce [5,14,16], transition metal catalysts (Ni, Mo, Fe, Ni2P, Co, Mo2C) are widely studied for HDO of fatty acids [4,17–21], especially for the Ni-based catalyst, due to its high activity and readily available. In the case of Ni-catalyzed HDO reaction, the conversion of palmitic acid is mainly involved via HDCO and HDH2O routes [12,18], simultaneous forming deoxygenation products of n-C15 and n-C16. In this continuous reaction process, HAL is a key intermediate because its formation and transformation have a strong impact on the reaction pathways, overall reation rate and the distribution of n-C15 and n-C16. Nonetheless, the formation and next transformation of the HAL remain unclear in the reported literatures up to now, which is critical for deep understanding the HDO catalytic reaction routes and mechanism. On the other hand, although many literatures reported that the surface acidic nature of catalyst strongly affects the reaction routes and product distributions in the HDO reaction [22–24], the acid or base sites in the catalyst are also important influence factors for the formation and transformation of the HAL and HOL, which are scarcely any reported. Herein, in this work, Na-form and H-form mesoporous ETS-10 zeolites (NaMETS-10 and HMETS-10) with Lewis basicity and Brönsted acidity were prepared, respectively, and their supported Ni catalysts (Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10) were examined in the model reaction of palmitic acid HDO to investigate the formation and transformation pathways of HAL and HOL as well as their reversible transformation. The results show that the HAL was indeed formed from palmitic acid and HOL through control experiments and the kinetic calculations, and its next transformation orientation was strongly affaced by the Lewis basic and Brönsted acidic sites of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of mesoporous ETS-10 zeolite The mesoporous zeolite ETS-10 was synthesized hydrothermally from a titanosilicate gel using N,N-dimethyl-N-octadecyl-N-(3-triethoxysilylpropyl) ammonium bromide (TBOAT) as mesoscale template [25], and the molar composition in the titanosilicate gel was 5.76SiO2/TiO2/4.7Na2O/1.32K2O/163.13H2O/0.07TBOAT. In a typical run, 15.3 mL of sodium silicate aqueous solution (SiO2, 24.59 wt.%, Na2O, 6.82 wt.%) was mixed with 10 mL NaOH aqueous solution (NaOH, 2.7 wt.%) followed by addition of 11.8 mL KOH aqueous solution (KOH, 0.18 wt.%) and stirring at room temperature for 1 h. Then, 13 g TiCl3 hydrochloric solution (TiCl3, 17 wt.%) was slowly added. Finally, 6 mL TBOAT was added dropwise and further stirred for 2 h at room temperature. The obtained gel was transferred into a teflon-coated stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL) for hydrothermal crystallization at 230 °C for 72 h. The obtained sample was filtrated, washed, and then dried at 120 °C overnight, and further calcined at 400 °C for 3 h in air. The resulted material was basic mesoporous ETS-10, and denoted as NaMETS-10. The acidic sample of the H-form ETS-10 (HMETS-10) was obtained by ion-exchange of NaMETS-10 with ammonium nitrate solution (0.8 M) at 80 °C for 4 h, and followed by drying and calcination. The same procedure was repeated two times. 2.2 Catalyst preparation and pre-treatment Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts with Ni loading of 6.0 wt.% were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method using aqueous solution including a desired amount of nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O). In a typical run, the aqueous solution was firstly introduced into the powdered support. After impregnation, the samples were placed under ambient condition for 10 h and further dried at 100 °C for 10 h. Then, the dried samples were calcined from 100 to 400 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 and kept at 400 °C for 3 h. Prior to the test, The prepared catalysts were reduced at 400 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 and held at 400 °C for 3 h in hydrogen flow. 2.3 Support and catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the supports and catalysts were performed to verify the topological structure of the synthesized supports and catalysts on RIGAKU UltimalV diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms of the samples were measured to obtain the texture premeters and pore size distributuins on the Micromeritics ASAP 2020M apparatus at -196 °C. Before the measurement, the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 8 h. The temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) and CO chemisorption experiments were carried out on the same Micromeritics AutoChem ASAP 2920 instrument equipped with a TCD detector to inverstigate the reduction behavior of Ni species and the metal-support interaction as well as the metal dispersion, respectively. For the H2-TPR experiment, dried sample (100 mg) was placed in quartz reactor and heated from ambient temperature to 550 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in a gas mixture of H2-Ar (10 vol% H2). The analysis procedure of CO chemisorption refered to previously published work [26]. The ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiment was performed to measure the total acid density of the zeolite, which was also conducted on the Micromeritics AutoChem ASAP 2920 instrument. 200 mg of sample was placed into a quartz tube reactor and purged with a helium stream at 450 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 120 °C, the He stream was switched to 10 vol.% NH3-He mixed gas and continously flowed over the sample for 30 min. Afterthat, the sample was maintained at 120 °C for 2 h to remove physically adsorbed NH3 in a He stream, and then was heated at a rate of 10 °C min−1 from 120 to 580 °C. The infrared spectra of the pyridine (PY-IR) and pyrrole-chemisorbed (PR-IR) samples were obtained on a Bruker TENSOR 27 infrared spectrophotometer equipped with a reactor cell to characterize the acid-base properties of the H- and Na-form METS-10 samples, respectively. Before measurement, the samples were evacuated to 10−2 Pa at 100 °C for 10 h. After cooling to room temperature, pyridine steam was introduced into the sample cell by N2 stream until saturation adsorption, and then N2 was switched into the cell that was heated to 200 °C at 10 °C min−1 in flowing for 2.5 h to desorb the physorbed pyridine. Then, the spectrum was recorded at room temperature after deduction of the KBr spectrum. The pyrrole adsorbed IR spectrum was obtained using the same operation procedure except pyrrole stream instead of pyridine stream. The images of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were obtained to observe the particles size of metal Ni on a JEM-2100F microscope with a limited line resolution capacity of 1.4 Å at 200 kV. Before characterization, the samples were cut into thin slices and dropped onto a Cu-grid coated with carbon membrane. To obtain size distributions of the metal Ni, at least 40 TEM micrographs were measured for the reduced catalyst, including 400–500 particles were taken from different parts of each catalyst. The average Ni particle size (Daver ) was calculated according to the following equation: D a v e r = ∑ i = 1 n d i n where, n is the number of Ni particles and d i is the size of Ni particle. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were performed to explore the chemical valence of Ni species on two catalysts on an ESCALAB MK II system. Before analysis, the calcined catalysts were reduced in a H2 gas at 400 °C for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the reduced catalyst was transferred into a bottle filled with absolute cyclohexane under hydrogen stream. Prior to the XPS experiments, the cyclohexane was removed and the residual was quickly moved to a specimen stage, and then transferred into the analysis chamber. To check the change of Ni content in the fresh and spent catalysts, the Ni content was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometery (ICP–OES) on Aglient 7800, and the Ni loading on the fresh Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 was 5.63 and 5.64 wt.%, respectively (Table S1). 2.4 Transformation of palmitic acid (or hexadecanol) to hexadecanal experiment The experiments of the formation of hexadecanal over Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 were performed in a 300 mL autoclave (model 4566 and controller 4848, Parr Instrument) for given reaction time at 220∼260 °C under variable H2 pressure. A typical run, 1.0 g reactant was dissolved in dekalin (100 mL), and 0.4 g reduced catalyst was charged into the autoclave under N2 stream. The autochave was sealed and purged into H2 with several times to remove air. When the autoclave was heated to a designed temperature, the stirring speed was adjusted at 500 rpm followed by pruging H2 to a set pressure. The collected liquid mixtures were analyzed using eicosane as an internal standard on the Agilent 7890B GC equipped with HP-5 chromatographic column (30 m×0.320 mm×0.25 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The conversion (C) and product selectivity (S) were determined by the followed equations: C = moles of reacted reactant moles of initial reactant × 100 % S = moles of each product moles of reacted reactant × 100 % 2.5 Palmitic acid HDO at high H2 pressure The palmitic acid HDO was also carried out in the 300 mL autoclave (model 4566). The typical reaction condition was kept coincident with above, and except the temperature was reached 260 °C and hydrogen pressure was up to 4.0 MPa. Before activity evaluations, a contrast experiment was performed under N2 pressure of 4.0 MPa to confirm that the direct decarboxylation reaction of palmitic acid was difficult on the both catalysts (please see Supporting Information, Fig. S1). To obtain the intrinsic activity of the catalysts, the mass transfer limitation was eliminated in advance. To role out the external mass transfer, the stirring rate was changed from 100∼700 rpm over these two catalysts, and the results were shown in Fig. S2. It showed that the conversion of palmitic acid was increased linearly with stirring rate untile the stirring rate exceed 300 rpm, indicating that the external mass transfer could be eliminated when the the stirring rate overtop 300 rpm. Therefore, 500 rpm was employed for the HDO reaction in the following studies to ensure the absence of external mass transfer. The internal mass transfer limitation was validated by the Weisz–Prater Criterion (C wp), which was shown in below [27,28]. C WP = r obs ρ c R P 2 D eff C S where, r obs is initial reaction rate, mol·kg−1·s−1; Rp is the catalyst particle radius, m; ρ c is the bulk density of catalyst bed, kg·m−3; D eff is effective diffusivity, m2·s−1; CS is bulk concentration of palmitic acid at the external surface of the catalyst, mol·m−3. The C WP values for Ni@HMETS-10 and Ni@NaMETS-10 were 0.00034 and 0.00036, less than 1 (the detail please see Supporting Information), indicating that the internal diffusion limitation can be neglected under the selected reaction conditions. In this case, intrinsic HDO activity of the catalysts could be assessed using r o b s that was calculated using the following equation: r o b s = n W × d x d t Turnover frequency (TOF) for the catalysts were calculated by the followed equations on the basis of published literature [26,29]: TOF = r o b s M where, robs is the initial reaction rate (Fig. S3–S5, mol·kg−1·s−1), n is the initial amount of reactant (mol), x is the conversion of reactant, W is the catalyst mass (kg), t is the reaction time (s), and dx is the differential of the reactant conversion, and M is the number of moles of effective metal sites, which was determined by the CO uptake (mol·kg−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Support and catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of supports and catalysts are showed in Fig. 2 a. The NaMETS-10 and HMETS-10 samples exhibit the typical diffraction peaks at 2θ=5∼50°, which are associated with ETS-10 structure (Fig. 2a) [30]. After loading of Ni and reduction, the well-resolved peaks of the catalysts are still retained, nevertheless, the intensity of diffraction peaks is slightly weakened. It is worth noting that no diffraction peaks associated with Ni nanoparticle were defected in the catalysts, suggesting that the metal Ni could be present in form of small nanoparticles sizes below the XRD detection limit, less than about 5 nm [14,31]. N2 sorption isotherms of the NaMETS-10 and HMETS-10 supports in (Fig. 2b) presented a type H3 hysteresis loop, illustrating the zeolite crystals have mesoporous structure. The corresponding pore size were mainly concentrated at 10.3 nm (insert in Fig. 2b). The types of isotherms, and the shape of mesopore size distributions of the catalysts were almost similar to those of supports (Fig. 2c), which implied that the mesoporous structure was impregnable after Ni loading. The texture parameters of the zeolites and catalysts displayed in Table S2. The Ni@NaMETS-10 (311 m2 g−1 , 0.18 cm3 g−1) and Ni@HMETS-10 (319 m2 g−1, 0.16 cm3 g−1) have similar BET surface area and mesoporus volume. The basicity of the NaMETS-10 was examined using pyrrole as a probe molecule that can chemisorb on Lewis bases (Fig. 2d). The characteristic peaks of N-H stretching at about 2926 and 2846 cm−1 reveal the presence of Lewis basic sites, which was originated from the framework Ti atom (TiO6)2− in octahedral coordination on NaMETS-10 sample [25,30,32]. The acidity of the NaMETS-10 and HMETS-10 was measured by NH3-TPD technique, and the results are shown in (Fig. 2d). Both samples have obvious desorption NH3 signal in the range of 200∼250 °C, indicating that NaMETS-10 and HMETS-10 have abundant weak acidic sites [27]. Nevertheless, the NH3 desorption signal for NaMETS-10 is stronger than that for HMETS-10, suggesting that NaMETS-10 has larger weak acidic sites than HMETS-10 sample. The total acid concentration was calculated and showed that NaMETS-10 had larger total acidic density (662 μmol g−1) than HMETS-10 (442 μmol g−1, Table S3). To further inverstigate the acid nature of NaMETS-10 and HMETS-10, PY-IR spectra were performed using pyridine as a probe molecule that can chemisorb on the Brönsted and Lewis acid sites (Fig. 2f). For NaMETS-10 sample, an absorption band appears at 1445 cm−1 assocaited with Lewis acid sites, which could be originated from by the balanced cations of Na+ and K+. For HMETS-10 sample, the intensity for absorption band (1445 cm−1) assocaited with Lewis acidity was reduced, and a new absorption band at 1545 cm−1 assigned to Brönsted (B) acid sites appeared (Fig. 2e). The Brönsted acidity was came from the H+ ions that located in ion-exchanged sites or situated neighbor TiO6 octahedra after calcination of the NH4-form zeolite (for details please see Supporting Information, Fig. S6) [33,34]. Thus, compared with NaMETS-10 zeolite, although the number of Lewis acidity and basicity on HMETS-10 zeolite was decreased, HMETS-10 zeolite had numerious B acidity. In addition, combination of the NH3-TPD and PY-IR spectra, it can be concluded that the NaMETS-10 zeolite has Lewis acidity with acid concentration of 662 μmol g−1, while HMETS-10 has both B and L acidity, and the B and L acid concentration was 215.3 and 226.7 μmol g−1 (Table S3), respectively. The Ni dispersion on both the catalysts were observed by TEM technique (Fig. 3 a and b). It is clear that the metal nanoparticals with relatively uniform size of 2∼ 4 nm highly dispersed in the mesoporous channels and on the microprous surface of the both catalysts. The high resolution TEM image in Fig. S7 shows that the d-spacing (0.204 nm) of metal particle is in agreement with the spacing of Ni {1 1 1} [35], demonstrating the metal are active Ni0. It seems that the particle size of Ni on Ni@HMETS-10 is slightly samller than that of Ni@NaMETS-10. Thus, the average particle size (Daver ) of metal Ni on these two catalysts was calculated. The Ni Daver on Ni@NaMETS-10 is 3.2 nm, slightly higher than that on Ni@HMETS-10 (2.9 nm, Fig. S8, Tabe S2). Because the HMETS-10 and NaMETS-10 have similar BET surface area and mesoporous volumes (Table S2), thus the difference in the Ni particle size on the two catalysts could be due to the change in the surface properties of HMETS-10 and NaMETS-10 materials. The B acidic sites of the HMETS-10 may strengthen metal-support interaction, leading to the formation of relatively smaller Ni nanoparticles on the Ni@HMETS-10 catalsyt. Many literatures have reported the presence of relatively strong interaction beween the acidic hydroxyl groups on zeolite and the various metals, such as Ni, Mo and Pt [26,31,36]. The difference in metal-support interation between Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalsyts was surveyed by H2-TPR experiment of the calcined catalysts (Fig. 3c). H2-TPR profile of the Ni@NaMETS-10 showed two reduction peaks centered at 308 and 452 °C, along with one shoulder peak at 261 °C. The low temperature at 261 and 308 °C are associated with the reduction of Ni2+ species in the form of Ni oxide located in two different microenvironments: the former could be Ni2+ species situated on the catalyst surface, and the latter could be Ni2+ species located in interior mesoporous channels [26]. The high temperature at 452 °C could be reduction of tetrahedral Ni2+ species in interaction strong with support. While for Ni@HMETS-10 sample, only one low reduction temperature peak appears at 334 °C, and two high temperation peaks appear at 462 and 516 °C, which are higher than those on Ni@NaMETS-10. These results indicated the presence of relatively strong metal-support interaction on Ni@HMETS-10. The chemical valence of metal Ni species in the reduced catalysts are inverstigated by XPS tenchnique (Fig. 3d). The Ni 2p2/3 XPS spectrum was decomposed into three peaks with binding energies at 852.8∼852.9, 854.4∼854.5 and 856.2∼856.4 eV, which are assigined to zero-valent metal Ni, NiO and tetrahedral Ni2+ species, respectively (Table S4) [37–40]. The presence of NiO in the catalyst could be caused by a superficial oxidation during sample transfer from bottle to XPS analysis room [26]. The tetrahedral Ni2+ species exised in the catalyst was due to the fact that the Ni2+ species interacted too strongly with support to be reduced at low reduction temperature (400 °C). The atomic percentages of differernt Ni species listed in Table S4 showed that Ni@NaMETS-10 has a slighlty higher Ni0 (37.7%) than Ni@HMETS-10 (35.7%) catalyst (Table S4). This is could be attributed to the relatively weak nickel–support interaction, which was consistent with H2-TPR results. The XPS results indicated the Ni species are present in the form of metal Ni0 in both catalysts, which is inline with TEM results. As a consequence, Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts have similar texture property parameters and pore size, but the B acid sites of HMETS-10 have strengthen the metal-support interaction, leading to the formation of relatively samll Ni particles on Ni@HMETS-10 in comparation with that on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst. 3.2 Hexadecanal formation in the palmitic acid HDO reaction 3.2.1 Determination of the reaction temperature and the hydrogen partial pressure It has been reported that the HAL is sensitive to reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure [19,24], which makes it impossible to study its formation and transformation pathways. Therefore, the effects of reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure on the product distribution over the two catalysts were surveyed to determine the reaction conditions for the formation and transformation behaviors of HAL in palmitic acid HDO reaction. Fig. 4 a and b give the product distributions over Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts in reaction temperature range of 220∼260 °C at a fixed pressure of 4.0 MPa H2. When the reaction temperature was 220 °C, HDO reaction did not occur (Fig. 4a and b). As reaction temperature was raised to 230 °C, a solo product of HOL was generated on both catalysts. As the reaction was carried out with 240, 250 and 260 °C, the HOL intermediate can convert to palmityl-palmitate (PP) and n-C15 over Ni@NaMETS-10, while on acidic Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst, in addition to PP and n-C15, the HOL can also transform into n-C16. Of course, the intermediate of HAL was not detected in both catalytic systems in the surveyed temperature range of 220∼260 °C. To further explore, the palmitic acid HDO experiment was performed over both catalysts with differernt hydrogen pressure at a constant temperature of 260 °C (Fig. 4c and d). It is exciting that the reaction operated at H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa, the HAL as a single product was detected in both catalytic systems. Nonetheless, when the reaction was operated at H2 pressure of 0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 3.0 MPa, the HAL was not detected. Other products, such as PP, n-C15 and n-C16, in particular, a large amount of HOL were formed. These results indicated that the HAL can be formed in the HDO of palmitic acid, and it can be rapidly transformed to HOL at high H2 pressure. In addition, from the product distribution in Fig. 4c and d, it can be concluded that the further transformation of the HAL is strongly depended on the H2 pressure. The H2 pressure can impact the adsorption of H2 on catalyt surface, which affects the intimacy beween H2 and palmitic acid or intermediates [13], leading to different product distribution under variable pressure. Therefore, the formation and transformation of HAL were detailedly investigated under low H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa and 260 °C in the next. 3.2.2 The formation and transformation of hexadecanal The formation and transformation of hexadecanal from palmitic acid The reaction proceeding of palmitic acid HDO over both catalysts under the H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa and reaction temperature of 260 °C are shown in Fig. 5 a and b. The initial product of HAL can be transformed to n-C15 at reaction time of 300 min on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst and at reaction time of 225 min on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst, respectively. The results suggested that the n-C15 was formed from HAL, not directly from the decarboxylation of palmitic acid. Meanwhile, the HAL was not further hydrogenated into HOL under H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa. In addition, the initial reaction rate of the palmitic acid on Ni@HMETS-10 and Ni@NaMETS-10 catalysts are calculated and the results are shown in Fig. S3 and Table 1 . The robs,1 of Ni@HMETS-10 (2.55×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1) is higher than that of Ni@NaMETS-10 (robs,1 =1.59×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1). The rate constant (k) of the palmitic acid transformation into HAL was also fitted based on the concentration variation of the reactants and products as a function of reaction time, ploted in Fig. 5c and d. The Ni@HMETS-10 has higher k 1,H (2.30×10−5 s−1) than Ni@NaMETS-10 (k 1,Na=2.0×10−5 s−1), which could be attributed to the synergistic effect of metal Ni and B acid sites existed in the catalyst. The samller the Ni crystal is, the higher hydrogenation activity has. Compared with Ni@NaMETS-10 (Daver =3.2 nm), the Ni@HMETS-10 with small Ni crystallite size (Daver =2.9 nm, Table S2) enhanced the hydrogenation activity. In addition, Anna Vikár and coworkers have reported that OH group in aluminium oxide can condensate with carboxy hydroxyl group in fatty acids to form carboxylated groups that followed by hydrogenolysis to form fatty aldehyde [14]. In our case, the hydrogen proton in B acid sites would be inclined to interacted with the carboxy hydroxyl group of the palmitic acid, weakening the C-O bond and benefiting the cleavage of the C–O bond by attacking of the dissociation hydrogen on the metal Ni sites, followed by the formation of HAL after elimination of H2O (Fig. S9). The formation and transformation of hexadecanal from hexadecanol The HOL HDO was also carried out to investigate whether the HAL was formed under the controlled H2 pressure (0.1 MPa) at 260 °C (Fig. 6 a and b). The results show that when reaction time was less than 5 min, only HAL was detected on both Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts. With the reaction proceeding, the n-C15 was formed and its selectivity increased with decreasing the HAL selectivity. The amount of the increased n-C15 is considerable to the amount of the decreased HAL, indicating that the n-C15 should be obtained from the decarbonylation of HAL. In addition, robs,2 (5.74×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) of the HOL HDO reaction over Ni@NaMETS-10 is lower than that of Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst (6.85×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1, Fig. S4, Table 1). The k 2 for the conversion of the HOL to HAL on Ni@NaMETS-10 (4.9×10−4 s−1) is also lower than that for Ni@HMETS-10 (5.5×10−4 s−1, Fig. 6c and d). The higher reaction over Ni@HMETS-10 should be due to the presence of relatively small crystallite sizes of active Ni metals and high metal dispersion. The reaction pathway of the hexadecanal Combining the results of the experiments and kinetic calculations on the formation of HAL from palmitic acid and HOL and its further transformation, the possible reaction pathways for the HDO of palmitic acid and HOL in the presence of 0.1 MPa H2 are proposed and shown in Scheme 1 . As to palmitic acid HDO, the carboxylic group of palmitic acid was initial reduced to transform HAL intermediate, which was catalyzed either solely by metal Ni sites on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst or synergistically by metal Ni and B acidic sites on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst. The formed HAL would be converted into n-C15 on Ni sites with the scission of C–C bonds by the decarbonylation route, which was impregnable with the surface acid-base properties of the catalyst. In addition, the the direct decarboxylation of palmitic acid to form n-C15 did not occur on both catalysts. As to HOL HDO reaction, HAL was also an initial product from the dehydrogenation process of HOL on metal Ni sites, and followed by decarbonylation to form n-C15. Notably, the HOL can not converted into n-C16 via the hydrogenation-dehydration route on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst. This could be because in continuous dehydration/hydrogenation process, fatty alcohols was firstly transformed into alkene via dehydration that then rapidly hydrogenated to convert n-C16 [13,43]. Thus, it can be inferred that the dehydration of fatty alcohols is difficult to occur under low pressure [13], which is dependent on H2 pressure. 3.3 The overall reaction network and kinetics of palmitic acid HDO The palmitic acid HDO experiments on the Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts were also performed at reaction temperature of 260 °C with high H2 pressure of 4.0 MPa. The conversion of palmitic acid and selectivitis of the products as a function of the reaction time are showed in Fig. 7 a and b. For the Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst with Lewis basicity, the palmitic acid conversion was linearly increased with reaction time and up to 100% at 240 min, and n-C15, n-C16, HOL and PP were formed, except HAL. HOL selectivity rapidly reached plateau of 93%, and n-C15 and PP selectivity was minimal at reaction time of 15 min. With prolonging the reaction time, HOL selectivity was gradually reduced, and the decreased HOL mainly convert into n-C15 (92%), versus small n-C16 (8%) at 540 min. The selectivity of PP climbed up in the beginning and then declined to zero. The PP was resulted from the esterification of the formed HOL and unreacted palmitic acid, which can transformed into HOL via hydrogenolysis route on metal Ni sites. For the Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst with acidity, the change trend in palmitic acid conversion and product (n-C15, n-C16, PP, HOL) selectivity were similar to those on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst, and the HAL was also not detected. Nevertheless, the final product distribution on Ni@HMETS-10 was distinguishing with Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst: n-C16 selectivity was increased by a large margin to 44%, n-C15 selectivity was reduced to 48%, and a new product of isohexadecane (iso-C16) was generated with selectivity of 8%. The enhanced n-C16 selectivity revealed that the higher activity of Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst towards the scission of C–O bonds than the C–C bonds due to the presence of B acid sites, which can promote HOL to n-C16 via continuous dehydration/hydrogenation process. Notably, a high alkane yield (100%) was obtained over both catalysts, which is comparable to or superior to the reported catalysts found in Table S5 (detailed description presented in Table S5). As the data shown in Fig. 7, HAL was not detected on both catalytic systems with high H2 pressure of 4.0 MPa. Nevertheless, comparation of the reactions performed at 0.1 MPa H2 (Figs. 5 and 6), the HAL should be initially generated from the hydrogenation/dehydration of palmitic acid. Once HAL formed, it was hydrogenated to HOL and simultaneously decarbonylated to n-C15 at high H2 pressure. This can be supported by the another hydrogenation experiment using HAL as a starting reactant (4.0 MPa H2, 260 °C, the detailed see Supporting Information, Table S6). HOL (58%) and n-C15 (40%) was rapidly formed under HAL conversion of 91% at 1 h over Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst. Thus, the transformation between HAL and HOL was invertible in the palmitic acid HDO at high pressure. Peng et al. adopted theoretical calculations to illustrate the presence of rapid transformation equilibrium between HAL and HOL at high pressure, and HOL is stable existence in the reaction system [44]. The HAL transformed from either palmitic acid or HOL underwent decarbonylation process to n-C15. As a conclusion, the overall reaction network on the Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts in high-pressurized H2 was proposed and is shown in Scheme 2 . On Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst with basicity, palmitic acid was mainly converted into n-C15 via decarbonylation of the HAL intermediate. On Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst with B acidity, the HAL intermediate was involved two parallel transformation pathways: one was direct decarbonylation of HAL to n-C15, the other was hydrogenation of HAL to HOL that can be further synergistically catalyzed by the B and Ni sites to n-C16 or iso-C16. On the other hand, because the hydrogenation of palmitic acid to HAL is rate-determining step [24], the conversion of palmitic acid to HOL would be influenced by the rate of the HAL formation. The initial reaction rate of palmitic acid HDO reaction over Ni@HMETS-10 (robs,3 =1.42×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) is higher than that over Ni@NaMETS-10 (robs,3 =1.31×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1, Fig. S5, Table 1), which is consistent with the reaction activity of the Ni@HMETS-10 (robs,1 =2.55×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1) and Ni@NaMETS-10 (robs,1 =1.59×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1) in the low H2 pressure. These results demonstrate that the rapid formation of HAL contributes to the high acitivity of the palmitic acid HDO reaction at high H2 pressure. Considering the BET surface area and mesoporous volume of the two catalysts were similar to each other, the acitivity discrepancy should be caused by the metal Ni dispersion and surface acid-base properties. Ni@HMETS-10 has a higher CO uptake of 3.64×10−2 mol kg−1 than Ni@NaMETS-10 (2.61×10−2 mol kg−1, Table S2), which could provide more active Ni sites for H2 dissocaition and enhance its HDO activity [26,45]. In addition, the B acid sites on Ni@HMETS-10 pomote the conversion of palmitic acid via dehydration/hydrogenation route (Fig. S9). In reaction pathway (Scheme 2), because HAL intermediate can rapidly hydrogenate to HOL, and the HAL and HOL are in a dynamic equilibrium, the reaction pathway was simplified to calculate the rate constant (k), and the results are shown in Scheme 3 . The k 3,H of palmitic acid to HOL on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst (0.61×10−2 s−1) is higher than that on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst (k 3,Na= 0.55×10−2 s−1), which was the same trend with the low pressure of 0.1 MPa hydrogen (k 1,H(2.30×10−5 s−1) > k 1,Na(2.0×10−5 s−1)), indicating that the rapid formation of HAL in the initial stage could promote the formation of large amounts of HOL at high H2 perssure. Notably, a high k 4,Na of the HOL converted into n-C15 on Ni@NaMETS-10 (k 4,Na = 0.91×10−2 s−1) catalyst as compared to Ni@HMETS-10 (k 4,H=0.54×10−2 s−1) catalyst, which was opposite to that (k2 ,Na < k2, H) for the key step of the HOL transformation into HAL at low hydrogen pressure of 0.1 MPa. This could be caused by the following reasons: The metal Ni is widely considered as the active site for the scission of αC–βC bonds of the aldehydes [46]. Although the Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst has lower Ni dispersion (2.61×10−2 mol kg−1) than Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst (3.64×10−2 mol kg−1), Ni@NaMETS-10 has higher scission ability of αC–βC bonds than Ni@HMETS-10. This could be caused by the surface acid-base difference between this two catalysts. The Ni@NaMETS-10 support not only has Lewis acidic sites but also possesses Lewis basic sites. The Lewis basic sites on Ni@NaMETS-10 might accelerate the decarbonylation of the HAL to n-C15, resulting in the equilibrium to move forward for the reaction of HOL→HAL under reaction conditions, and enhaced the reaction activity. The k 5,H and k 4,H over Ni@HMETS-10 is almost equal to each other, leading to the n-C15 selectivity similar to n-C16 selectivity over Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst. Comprared with k 6,H (0.49×10−3 s−1) on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst, the high k 6,Na (0.61×10−3 s−1) could be due to the presence of Lewis basicity on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst, which promote the esterification process of fatty acids and alcohols, which can be supported by the HDO experiment on metal-free zeolite catalysts using palmitic acid and HOL as starting materials (Fig. S10, the details please see Supporting Information). The initial reaction rate (PA+HOL→PP) over NaMETS-10 (robs,4 =1.31×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1, Fig. S11a) is high than that over NaHETS-10 (robs,4 =0.93×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1, Fig. S11b). On the other hand, the B acidic sites on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst promote the hydrogenesis reaction of PP to generate HOL on metal Ni sites, leading to k 7,H (0.89×10−1 s−1) almost ten times higher than k 7,Na (0.71×10−2 s−1). Based on the characterization and activity results, the activity discrepancy and reaction pathway orientation between Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 could be caused by the difference in the surface acid-base properties of the catalyst. NaMETS-10 has a large amount of Lewis acid sites with concentration of 662 μmol g−1 and abundant Lewis basicity. In contrast, HMETS-10 has relatively few L acid (226.7 μmol g−1) and Lewis basicity, but HMETS-10 has numerious B acid with concentration of 215.3 μmol g−1. The B acidic sites in the HMETS-10 can strengthen metal-support interaction, leading to the formation of relatively smaller and highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles (Daver = 2.9 nm, M=3.64×10−2 mol kg−1) on the Ni@HMETS-10 catalsyt, as compare to Ni@NaMETS-10 (Daver = 3.2 nm, M=2.61×10−2 mol kg−1), which was demonstrated by H2-TPR, TEM and CO chemisorption. Therefore, although NaMETS-10 has large acid concentration, the NaMETS-10 supported Ni catalyst still exhibits lower reaction activity (robs,3 =1.31×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) than HMETS-10 supported Ni catalyst (robs,3 =1.42×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1). Nevertheless, TOF3 value for Ni@HMETS-10 (0.04 s−1) is comparable to Ni@NaMETS-10 (0.05 s−1, Table 1). A similar results (robs,2 and TOF2) were also obtained over Ni@HMETS-10 and Ni@NaMETS-10 catalysts (Table 1). The higher r obs ,2 and robs,3 for Ni@HMETS-10 should be caused by the presence of abundant active Ni sites with relatively samll particles sizes [29,47]. In addition, the Brönsted acid and Lewis basic sites on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst jointly contributed to promote the palmitic acid conversion via the two paralleled HDCO and HDH2O reaction pathways. The B acid sites can promote the cleavage of the C–O bond in HOL by attacking of the dissociation hydrogen on the metal Ni sites [43], which favor the formation of hexadecylene after elimination of H2O and then hydrogenated to form n-C16. Meanwhile, the Lewis basic sites on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst can also promote the decarbonylation of the hexadecanal on the metal Ni sites to n-C15. Therefore, the deoxygenation of palmitic acid on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst involved two paralleled HDCO and HDH2O reaction pathways, yielding similar product selecitvity for n-C15 (48%) and n-C16 (44%). In contrast, the HDCO routes was dominant on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst in the palmitic acid HDO reaction, giving a high selectivity of n-C15 (92%). This is due to the presence of aboundant basic sites. To inverstigate structure stability of the catalyst, the spent catalysts were characterized by XRD, XPS, TEM and ICP-OES. The XRD patterns of spent catalysts showed that the characteristic diffraction peaks of ETS-10 structure were maintained well, and no other diffraction peaks associated with nickel or nickel oxide phases were detected (Fig. S12a). This result suggested that the nickel species could be highly dispersed in the spent catalysts, and its particle size was below the XRD detection limit (<5 nm). The Ni 2p2/3 XPS spectra of the spent catalysts displayed three peaks for Ni0 (852.8∼852.9 eV), NiO (854.2∼854.4 eV) and tetrahedral Ni2+ species (856.1∼856.2 eV, Fig. S12b). Compared with fresh catalysts, the atomic percentage of Ni0 was slightly decreased, while the atomic percentage of NiO was increased on the spent Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts. The increase in atomic percentage for NiO could be due to that partial Ni0 was oxidized by the surface water produced from the HDO reaction or some Ni0 was oxidized by the oxygen in the air during catalyst recovery process. The TEM images showed that there was an inconspicuous increase in the size of the Ni phases on the spent Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 (Fig. S12c and d), as compared to their corresponding fresh catalysts. The ICP-OES shows that the Ni content on the spent Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 remained at 5.62 and 5.64 wt.%, suggesting that Ni metal in the Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts have a good resistance for leaching. All these characterzation results confirmed that the intrinsic structure of the Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 catalysts was maintained well. 4 Conclusion The Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10 with high dispersion of metal Ni have been prepared, and applied in the hydrogenation of HAL, HOL and palmitic acid at different reaction conditions. The HAL was indeed formed from either the hydrogenation/dehydration palmitic acid or the dehydrogenation of HOL, and its next transformation was dependent on the H2 pressure and surface acid-base properties of the catalysts. At 0.1 MPa H2 pressure, the initial product of the HAL, transformed from the palmitic acid and HOL, was underwent decarbonylation process to form n-C15 on both catalysts. At 4.0 MPa H2 pressure, on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst with L basic sites, palmitic acid was mainly converted into n-C15 (92%) via decarbonylation of the HAL intermediate. On Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst with B acidity and L basic sites, the transformation of HAL involved HDCO and HDH2O reaction pathways, yielding n-C15 (48%), n-C16 (44%) and iso-C16 (8%). In addition, the initial reaction rate and rate constant on Ni@HMETS-10 were higher than those on Ni@NaMETS-10 catalyst at the 0.1 and 4.0 MPa H2 pressure, due to the presence of B acid sites and high dispersion of metal Ni on Ni@HMETS-10 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous ETS-10 zeolites supported Ni catalysts (Ni@NaMETS-10 and Ni@HMETS-10) were applied in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of palmitic acid to investigate the formation and transformation pathways of hexadecanal (HAL) and reaction activity. Experiment results verified that HAL was an initial product in the HDO reaction under 0.1 MPa H2 pressure, and Ni@HMETS-10 exhibits higher activities (robs,1 =2.55×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1, robs,2 = 6.85×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) than Ni@NaMETS-10 (robs,1 =1.59×10−4 mol kg−1 s−1, robs,2 =5.74×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) due to the presence of Brönsted acid sites and highly dispersed Ni particles. At high H2 pressure (4.0 MPa), the acid-base properties of the support affected the transformation of HAL and the reaction pathways. The abundant Lewis basic sites on Ni@NaMETS-10 can promote the decarbonylation of the HAL and the HDCO route are dominate. Brönsted acid and Ni sites on Ni@HMETS-10 synergistically catalyzed the deoxygenation of palmitic acid via two parallel HDH2O and HDCO routes with a higher reaction rate (1.42×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1) than Ni@NaMETS-10 (1.31×10−3 mol kg−1 s−1). The reaction rate constants of each step in reaction routes on both catalysts were supplemented.
coredata.dc:title: The formation and transformation of hexadecanal influence on reaction pathway and activity in the palmitic acid hydrodeoxygenation over mesoporous ETS-10 supported Ni catalyst
